thread.title: EDGE leaders questioned by Memphis and Shelby County officials
thread.title_full: EDGE leaders questioned by Memphis and Shelby County officials

author: Linda A. Moore
title: EDGE leaders questioned by Memphis and Shelby County officials
text:
EDGE does not control who is hired by companies that receive local PILOTs, has issued far fewer PILOTs than has been publicly reported and can make changes to how it operates, but not without ramifications.
Those were some of the questions answered by leaders with the Memphis and Shelby County Economic Development Growth Engine, who met on Monday with city and county elected officials to discuss the development incentive program called payment in lieu of taxes, or PILOT.
Organized by Memphis city councilwoman and EDGE board member Wanda Halbert , the meeting also was attended by Shelby County commissioners Steve Basar , an EDGE board member, Justin Ford , Eddie Jones and Van Turner .
Members of both bodies have expressed confusion about EDGE, Halbert said, and have questioned EDGE's power and ability to act without city or county approval.
They quizzed EDGE president and CEO Reid Dulberger and board chairman Al Bright.
EDGE was created in 2011 by a joint resolution of the council and commission to function as the centralized public sector development corporation, Dulberger said.
Companies issued PILOT incentives have created 18,900 jobs, EDGE officials said.
But Halbert questioned why, with high unemployment and poverty rate, EDGE does not require companies that benefit from Memphis and Shelby County tax breaks to hire locally.
"How do we monitor exactly what Memphis and Shelby County are getting for these tax incentives?" she asked.
When residency requirements were tried by another development entity, interest in the city "dried up," Dulberger said, because companies can easily locate across the state line and still benefit from the city's airport and other infrastructures.
"We don't believe a residency requirement is enforceable. We don't know if it's legal," he said. "We also strongly believe that it will hurt our ability to retain and create jobs here in the city and the county."
Also EDGE has 26 active PILOTS still in "ramp up," or the early stages, of hiring and 47 that are past "ramp up," Dulberger said, not the 458 that had been reported by some outlets during the recent city election.
There were also questions about a proposed plan for EDGE to take over operation of the Community Redevelopment Agency, a city/county organization that reviews Tax Incremental Financing projects, and has seen two projects in 15 years.
With no staff, CRA approached the EDGE board about assistance, Bright said.
Regardless, Basar said, there should be no arrangements made between EDGE and the CRA without the approval of the commission and the city council.
Overall, the meeting was helpful, Dulberger said.
"What they asked is doable," he said. "The question is, what are the consequences."
